As others are noting there is likely action coming to toughen immigration requirements on people from countries including Syria, Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen. For resolution of the question this might be a little trickier. A Trump action could cite specific reasons for restrictions such as terrorism state sponsor (and of interest here is that Iran, Sudan and Syria - the three designated state sponsors of terrorism - are amongst the countries concerned) or it could use more fuzzy language like "to the extent permitted by law" which might rely on terrorist designations as a basis for the action rather than explicitly citing this as the reason in the order. That said, the question notes only overlap between a designated country and one from which immigration is suspended, rather than citing it as a specific reason for the new restriction.  Two other points. "Suspend" suggests total ban rather than simply some manner of "extreme vetting" or additional restriction. This is probably where the question hinges - the requirement for a total suspension. Secondly, the question is "immigration" rather than refugees or asylum thus a specific legal category. So, something is coming (hence significantly bumping my probability forecast) but hedging on whether it is a total suspension on immigration specifically. When questioned about this topic on the television news show Meet The Press, Thomas Barrack, friend and advisor to Trump, was non-committal, but reiterated his belief that a temporary suspension was a good idea. This indicates to me that the intention remains, although the path toward implementation contains some challenges. (+10) Despite Trump's inaugural speech vow to " ... unite the civilized world against radical Islamic terrorism, which we will eradicate completely from the face of the earth," I'm not sure Trump will actually do anything that will bring too much intellectual focus upon the amorphous concept of "terrorism." As it stands now, terrorism is the gravy train that drives funding of the military-industrial complex. It is what stands in the way of America enjoying a "peace dividend." To do something specific, something definite, in this regard runs the risk that public discourse rises to clarify the concept; and such clarification would mean restriction of funding to some. Questions such as: "Why this country and not that?" and "What is the evidence relied upon to designate a country as a state sponsor of terrorism?" are generally not the sort of questions the public is encouraged to consider. A lot of mischief can be accomplished so long as terrorism remains an ill-defined boogeyman.

Comment: I disagree with this interpretation of the question (seems to moot its relevance since the U.S. surely already suspends immigration from all countries on both lists based on all sorts of classes/criteria) but am glad GJO answered/clarified. sus·pend
səˈspend/
verb
1. temporarily prevent from continuing or being in force or effect.
The US will may do it in the cases of some countries, but not in the case of every country that supports terrorism ( even if it´s just "passive" sponsering).

One of the last things that President Trump said about this before the election was that there would be "extreme vetting"--how this would be different than what is going on now was not elaborated upon.  I think we will essentially keep doing what we have been doing with only cosmetic changes.

It is possible that this would be attempted but the technicalities of defining a 'state sponsor of terroism or a terrorist safe haven' will prove to be very difficult. It would be diplomatically impossible to do this of Saudi Arabia for instance which will have some links with ISIS. However it is possible that they will do this and only include small countries like Yemen hence the double digit probability.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

State sponsors of terrorism: Iran, Sudan, Syria
Safe havens: Somalia, Mali, Philippines, Egypt, Iraq, Lebanon, Libya, Yemen, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Colombia, Venezuela Because of the extremely controversial blowback that would accompany this move, there would be no point in doing it to any country but those that have featured heavily in Trump's rhetoric. This means that we can almost certainly scrub out many of the above list (especially those that aren't related to Islamic terrorism, i.e. Colombia). The political blowback would be very heavy and would certainly alienate the country in question, along with its allies. It would illicit immediate retaliation on US nationals abroad as well. It would be a very painful move to make, especially just to appease Trump's base (many of whom seem to support him no matter what he does) immediately after the inauguration, when he's not feeling any pressure to act.  Another thing to think about: how large is the diaspora of the above countries in the USA (think: how big could the pushback be?)? There are hundreds of thousands of Syrian Americans and Iraqi Americans already in the USA, as well as large numbers of Pakistani, Afghani, and Somali Americans who are quite well-integrated. There is an incredible amount of religious diversity in many of these countries, and given that Trump's rhetoric has been about religion, not nationality, I don't see how it could be politically expedient to ban all Syrians (for example), when he really only cares about Muslims. Especially not within a short 3-month time period.  This all could change if there's a big attack in the USA or elsewhere before the question's end date, but at the moment I'd say it seems very unlikely. Probably more likely that he would ban Syrians (for example) entering as refugees and continue allowing those entering through the regular immigration process as usual, but that's not what the question is asking. And again, 3 months is probably not enough time for such a complex legal issue.
Thinking the political benefits on some country will be too tempting.

It has the deep support of Trump's populace base and will draw support from the great majority of Congressional Republicans and a considerable number of conservative Democrats.  Phrased this way, it skirts the less obvious intent of putting a ban on the entry of all Muslims, which would invite serious opposition, particularly on Constitutional grounds.  I believe that there is a greater chance of perceiving that the latter goal (banning all Muslims) could be largely accomplished in a practical way by making it less obvious to the eye. Wording of this sort on any legislation would go a long way toward fulfilling that goal; it will not fool many opponents, however, and therefore will promote fierce argument.  Nevertheless I believe such wording gives it a good chance of meeting the April 30th deadline   In light of the recent poorly designed executive order and the subsequent uproar it provoked, pivotal to whether this kind of action can effectively been implemented a second time will depend on how well the President's immediate actions in effecting a revised executive order as well as whether Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch faces a Democratic filibuster slowing down his confirmation.

Jeff Sessions, if approved by the Senate, will be the next Attorney General. As such, he would head the Department of Justice so the DOJ's Office of Legal Counsel, which advises other executive agencies on the constitutionality of their various policy actions,[1] would report directly to him. Sessions has been an influential advisor to Trump on immigration.[2] In the wake of the 12 June 2016 Orlando nightclub shootings by a U.S. citizen (born in the U.S.) who was the son of Afghan immigrants, Senators Sessions and Cruz sent a letter to the Obama administration criticizing its “inability to properly screen individuals from abroad,” juxtaposing this view with statistics on immigration to the U.S. by people from “Muslim-majority” countries.[3] In the wake of the same shooting, Trump pivoted away from calling for a temporary/conditional total ban on Muslims entering the U.S.[4] and toward calling for a ban on people from "terror prone" regions.[5] The phrase "terror prone" has long been used by Sessions to attribute terrorist attacks on the U.S. to immigrants who are in the U.S. as a result of immigration from the Middle East---immigration that may be allowed or prevented by changes to U.S. immigration policy.[6] At the Senate hearing on whether to confirm Sessions yesterday, Senator Hirono, a pro-immigrant/immigration advocate (and, as a Buddhist, the only member of the U.S. Senate expressing a religious affiliation that is not Christian or Jewish; there are no muslims in the Senate[7]), who described herself as the immigrant daughter of a woman who was fleeing sexual abuse, asked Sessions about his views on immigration. Sessions' (partial) response: "a preferable approach [to vetting immigrants] would be based on areas where we have an unusually high risk of terrorists coming in.”[8] ------------------------

Start with the outside considerations: percentage chance that any country would suspend immigration from a certain location where it feels it important to safeguarding national security - 90%. However, add the assumption that the country has extensive foreign alliances and relations and then factor in the repercussions that country may face from the countries to which it suspends immigration, as well as those countries' allies - minus 30% from the 90%.  Then add specific characteristics of the United States: it has changed its immigrations laws throughout its history, about once a generation to two generations. Many of these laws excluded specific groups. Add 20%. However, the shift in cultural values means that it's less acceptable to overtly exclude groups. Trump's language was therefore modified from banning Muslims to something he can package as non-discriminatory based on race or religion. Still, many view it as a ban on Muslims and he will take flack for it. Minus 10%.  Trump has repeatedly stated his intention to suspend immigration from regions with terrorism. He has stated he would do it in his first 100 days. However, Trump has often revised his commitments, by adding additional nuance or changing the meaning of his original wording to clarify "what he actually meant". Add 10%. Finally, taking this action could be done by Trump alone, without Congress, and with progress on Congress' agenda likely to be less smooth, he may want to clearly show results during his first 100 days. Further, he can make good on his pledge while avoiding implementing a ban from countries where it may harm U.S. diplomatic/military interests by choosing one or several countries of less consequence. Add 10%.  Total = 90% probability
